title: 114_hr5864
content: The "Mental Health Training Enhancement for First Responders Act of 2016" is focused on providing mental health training for law enforcement. Section 2991(b)(5)(I) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow funds for specialized mental health training for law enforcement officers. The training includes understanding mental illnesses, their impact, signs and symptoms, and stabilization. The specialized mental health training for law enforcement officers includes role play scenarios, group problem solving exercises, and addressing issues related to mental health crises. Funding is provided for States to create a database for public safety and outreach. Specialized mental health training for law enforcement officers includes addressing community-specific issues, involving mental health personnel and experienced officers, cross-training with mental health professionals, teaching verbal de-escalation skills, and featuring presentations from individuals who have recovered from mental health challenges. The training for call-takers and 911 dispatchers includes recommendations on identifying previous mental health issues, drug abuse, violence, or victimization in callers or at the address. The training for call-takers and 911 dispatchers includes determining if individuals pose a threat, if there is a weapon involved, and establishing best practices for handling emergency calls. Training for call-takers and 911 dispatchers includes asking concise questions prepared by law enforcement and mental health professionals, and accurately relaying information to emergency responders. SEC. 3 amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to place law enforcement officers at local education agencies and include mental health entities in the Ounce of Prevention Grant. SEC. 4 establishes the Community Schools Youth Services and Supervision Grant Program. SEC. 4 amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to include mental health entities in the Community Schools Youth Services and Supervision Grant Program.
